April 2022 County of Marin EMS ALS PR 3
ORAL ENDOTRACHEAL
INTUBATION PROCEDURE
Indications
• Severe ventilatory compromise where the airway cannot be adequately maintained by BLS
techniques
Equipment
Procedure preparation
• Battery powered laryngoscope handle
• Open airway and pre-oxygenate with
and blades, extra batteries and bulbs
BVM for 1-3 minutes with 100% O2
• Video Laryngoscope (if available)
• Avoid hyperventilation in cardiac arrest
• McGill forceps
• Select proper sized ETT and insert stylet
• Cuffed endotracheal tubes
• Select proper sized laryngoscope blade
• ETTI
and visualize larynx
• Lubricating jelly
• Suction as needed
• Disposable stylets
• Suction
• Pulse oximetry
• End Tidal CO2 detector
• Esophageal Detector Device (EDD)
Procedure
• Colorimetric CO2 device
• Provide continuous high flow oxygen • Capnometer or capnography
during procedure, if possible
• Under direct visualization, insert ETT
2-3cm past the cords.
• Each attempt should not exceed 30 SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONS
seconds, hyperventilating between
• Defibrillation should precede intubation in
attempts
VF/pulseless VT
• Remove stylet and inflate cuff
• Consider use of ETTI if difficult intubation
• If unsuccessful after 1 attempt, may
attempt King tube or iGel x1. If
unsuccessful with King tube or iGel, then
manage with BLS airway
• Verify placement using all of the following:
• Rise and fall of chest
• Absence of epigastric sounds
• Bilateral breath sounds Critical Information
• Presence of condensation in the tube
• Absolute contraindications:
• EDD or colorimetric CO2 device
• Patient fits on length based tape
• Capnometry/capnography
• Epiglottitis
• Secure the tube. Consider spinal
• Relative contraindications:
immobilization to prevent extubation
• Spontaneous respirations are present
• Reassess tube placement after each
• Responsive patient with intact gag
movement.
reflex
• If any doubt about placement, confirm by
• Suspected opiate overdose
capnography or direct visualization
• Profound hypoglycemia
